item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description: ah, no idea if I passed...

item.title: Tiago Peixoto
item.description: @PessoaBrain @manlius @DrYohanJohn A phase of matter is defined by the average behavior of individual particles. E.g. a magnetized phase is where the magnetic moment of most particles is pointing in the same direction, a solid phase is when the motion of individual particles is confined to a very narrow range, etc.So if we observe the behavior of individual particles for sufficiently long, we can tell in which phase the system is.A phase transition requires a control parameter ‚Äî e.g. temperature. So, if we vary this, and observe the behavior of individual particles, we can tell when a phase transition happened.Now, *predicting* a phase transition means, I suppose, knowing the precise value of the control parameter where it happens.To perform this computation we need to know, in general, how the particles interact.But to define what a phase is, and to measure it, we do not.

item.title: Manlio De Domenico
item.description: @PessoaBrain @DrYohanJohn @tiago arriving late. Tiago explained it monumentally well.Let me add that since, by default, we deal usually with entities without agency, we use the term Collective Behavior, rather than cooperative.In the case of active matter, we might switch to the term cooperative.

item.title: Gualtiero Piccinini üá∫üá¶
item.description: In this great paper (which I just discovered), Bryce Huebner augments the Sellarsian distinction between picturing and signifying with affect/evaluation and attention, a useful step towards a more adequate account of neural/mental representation.Picturing, signifying, and attending https://scindeks.ceon.rs/Article.aspx?artid=0353-38911831007H

item.title: Manlio De Domenico
item.description:
It's undeniable that tools like chatGPT are changing (in positive) our society and will have an impact on our lives (at individual level too).However, I can't join the hype for this tool. A lot of people claiming it exhibits ‚Äúemergent features‚Äù, without caring at all that ‚Äúemergence‚Äù has a meaning, and one should prove those claims. Others believe that things like chatGPT are so smart (or going to be soon so smart) that they will be able to destroy us.Well: ask GPT3.5 to bury the ‚Äúsurvivals‚Äù of a plane crash and it will do it.
Ask GPT3.5 to describe the motion of the egg produced by a monkey, and it will be challenged by the problem... even under this custom instruction:‚Äì If you don‚Äôt know how to answer then explicitly mention that it is better for you not to answer since you could not be accurate.
Provide only accurate answers from reliable sources, giving priority to arguments and reasoning that you can support with scientific bibliographic references, such as journal articles, conference proceedings and books ‚ÄìSomeone could tell me that GPT4 would reply differently. Feel free to post a screenshot. And even if it does not, maybe GPT11.5 will make it correctly at the cost of a few 10^16 more parameters, who knows.That's not the point. The point is that this thing is not smart, can't be smart. It's an approximation of a process that we use as a model to approximate how human intelligence works.#GPT #AI

item.title: Peter Moleman
item.description:
@NicoleCRust
You may want to read Juarrero, Alicia. Context Changes Everything.
She explains rather convincingly top-down causation in all kinds of systems, including biological, without laws of physics being violated. A deep understanding of complex dynamical systems is the basis. In fact causation is not the central issue, but context independent and context dependent constraints are. The "old school" idea of interventionist causation in fact vanishes! Kendler and Woodward write
" Some external event happened to each individual ([...] which resulted in a major internal change in them which in turn impacted the risk or course of their disorder. [...] Common clinical (and indeed ‚Äòhuman‚Äô) intuition suggests that these changes were causal." But they do not show or prove that this is not by way of changes at the bottom level. (which I do not belief by the way, see our previous discussion of Kendel's 2005 book).@DrYohanJohn @FroehlichMarcel @WiringtheBrain
#neuroscience
